messageBody:
Cédric,

Filtering was the point of the example, but Request is quite general. There
are static methods for creating a Request for a single class, a single
method of a single class, or a list of classes. The example could have been
changed to:
Request request= Request.classes(Example1.class, Example2.class);

More advanced users can implement their own Requests. Most test writers
won't see any of this plumbing, but it's nice to have the flexibility when
you need it.

Sincerely yours,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

wrote:
>
> Cedric,
>
> I don't understand your message. Subclasses of Filter can be defined
> anywhere.

Right, but one Filter class can only filter one Test class since it's tied
to a Request class:

Request request= Request.aClass(Example.class);

I was just pointing out that in my experience, filters that apply to the
entire test suite are more flexible and usually more useful than filters
that apply to one test class only.
